GUARDIANSHIP OF INFANTS
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.35 p.m.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Column: 689



    The existing Guardianship of Infants Ordinance (Chapter 16 of the Revised Edition), is based on the United Kingdom Guardianship of Infants Act, 1885, and is out of line with modern trends in family law, as exemplified, for example, in our Women's Charter, 1961, in that it gives the father a superior right to the mother in the matter of the guardianship and custody of children. The Ordinance applies to Muslims but would appear to be contrary to the Muslim law which, in this respect, gives equal rights to the father and the mother of the child; and in fact, in many cases, gives the mother a prior right to the care and the custody of very young children. It is, therefore, proposed to adopt the provisions of the more recent Guardianship of Infants Act, 1925, of the United Kingdom, which makes the welfare of the infant the paramount consideration in making orders for the guardianship and custody of children and gives the mother an equal right with the father in applying for such guardianship and custody.

    This Bill will remove the discrimination against married women and will be in line with the resolution of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations of 3rd August, 1955, which recommends that State members of the United Nations should take all necessary measures to ensure equality as between parents in the exercise of rights and duties with respect to their children.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. [Mr E. W. Barker].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

WIDOWS' AND ORPHANS'
PENSION (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

Column: 690



2.41 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill seeks to amend the Widows' and Orphans' Pension Ordinance (Chapter 61), under which every Government officer restricted to a monogamous marriage, except those who joined the service on or after 2nd March, 1961, was required to contribute towards a pension for his widow and orphans.

    Through an amendment to the Ordinance, such officers, where already contributing, were allowed an option to continue to contribute; to stop contributing and preserve the rights that had accrued to them; or to stop contributing and be paid an actuarily calculated sum. The law further provided for a period of six months within which these options were required to be exercised, commencing 1st April, 1965. It followed that bachelors, who contracted monogamous marriages prior to 1st April, 1965, were accorded these options as they had the status of contributors before that date.

    The law did not provide, however, for the cases of bachelors, who joined the service before 2nd March, 1961, the date prescribed in the Women's Charter for marriages thereafter to be monogamous, if they contracted marriage after 1st April, 1965.

    There is no provision for such officers to be enabled to choose to continue to contribute or to be excluded from contributing to their widows' and orphans' pension, and this Bill seeks to repair that omission and make legal provision for them to elect to become, or to continue as, contributors within one month of contracting monogamous marriages. Administrative action has already been taken to call upon the officers affected to opt whether to become contributors within a month of marriage. So this Bill will provide the necessary legal provision to regularise these cases in accordance with the intention of the law.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

STAMP (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.54 p.m.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Stamp Ordinance was not amended when Singapore was part of Malaysia. So the majority of amendments proposed in this Bill relate to textual and terminological changes which take account of Singapore's new status as an independent sovereign Republic. References to the Colony, the Federation of Malaya, the British Commonwealth, and so on, are to be appropriately amended in keeping with Singapore's new Constitution.

    The opportunity has also been taken to make certain other amendments. For example, section 35 (b) of the principal Ordinance, which exempted grants or leases made by the Government or under the Foreshores Ordinance, is to be deleted, as no good reason exists

Column: 693

for such exemption. Exemptions previously granted to the Malayan Railways under Schedule A, Article 53 (e) , and to the Co-operative Societies registered in the Federation of Malaya under section 35 are to be withdrawn, as such provisions are inappropriate in the laws of an independent Republic.

    Under Article 27 of Schedule A, counterparts and duplicates of instruments are liable to stamp duty, and the proposed amendment will exempt duplicates of instruments from such duty. This is particularly desirable as traders are required to retain duplicate copies of receipts issued under the Income Tax Ordinance. It was never intended that duty should be imposed on duplicate copies required for the purposes of the Income Tax Ordinance.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

ESTATE DUTY
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    In April 1965, the Malaysian Government passed an Act to vary the laws in force in Malaysia relating to estate duty when Singapore was in Malaysia. That Act provided for harmonisation of the law with Malayan legislation. It further transferred to Federal Authority functions under the Singapore Estate Duty Ordinance and made other amendments consequent upon the passing of the Malaysia Act. It is now necessary to amend the Estate Duty Ordinance to accord with the independent status of Singapore, to revert to the rates of

Column: 694

estate duty that were applicable to the amending legislation of Malaysia, and to make minor and consequential amendments.

    Clause 2 (b) amends the definition of "property" to exclude immovable property situate in Malaysia from liability to duty in Singapore, while clause 4 reverts the rates of duty payable in respect of property passing on the death of any person, dying domiciled in either Singapore or Malaysia, to the pre-Malaysian rates which become applicable except for the period January 1st to August 9th, 1965.

    Clause 12 re-enacts new provisions relating to circumstances in which postponement of payment of estate duty may be permitted. The existing provisions were considered to be too restrictive and are repealed by clause 10. Primarily, the object is to facilitate administration of estates and obviate undue hardships.

    Clause 14 repeals the provisions of section 44A relating to payment of duty into the joint account and complementary thereto. Clause 3 provides for accountability by the Commissioner by payment into the consolidated account.

    Clause 15 repeals the provisions of section 54 which provided for the entering into of agreements for the purpose of exchanging information with other countries. This power is necessarily inherent in the Minister without the need for formal agreements.

    For the purpose of reverting to the pre-Malaysian rates of duty, new Sixth and Seventh Schedules are added to the Ordinance by clause 16. The Sixth Schedule contains the rates applicable in respect of deaths before 1st January, 1965, and from 9th November, 1955, when the rates of duty were increased, and after Singapore Day, whilst the Seventh Schedule contains the Malaysian rates applicable to the period 1st January to 8th August, 1965.

    The purpose of the Estate Duties (Apportionment and Miscellaneous Provisions) was to provide for apportionment of duty in the case of persons dying prior to 1st April, 1946, domiciled or leaving assets in the Straits Settlements and in respect of which some

Column: 695

duty remained unpaid after the dissolution of the Straits Settlements. Whilst theoretically a case could still arise at the present time where death occurred prior to 1st April, 1946, in respect of which duty has not been paid, the likelihood is somewhat remote and hence there are amendments in clause 18 for its repeal.

    The remainder of the amendments are of a minor and consequential nature. They are necessitated either to accord with the independent status of Singapore-clauses 2 (a) , 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 13 and 17 - or consequential upon amendments already described in clauses 11 and 18.

    Sir, I beg to move.

amendment standing in the name of Mr Teong Eng Siong. Mr Teong.

    Head 1002 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1002 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1181.

    Mr Speaker, the Dewan Bahasa dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan was established in 1960 after Singapore had self-government. Its purpose is mainly to carry out campaigns for the study of the national language, to encourage the people to learn and use it, and also to help the Government implement its language policy. It is hoped that the different races in Singapore will be able to use a common language in the near future. Since the establishment of this Dewan, it has been working assiduously in the promotion of the national language. Two National Language Months were held this year and we received keen support from all sections of the people. Cultural groups and the Dewan co-operated in promoting the learning of the national language. Because of this joint effort, more and more non-Malays are studying the language. This can be seen from the number of people who took part in Malay examinations in recent years.

    Mr Speaker, when people are keenly responding to the movement, we find that there are two abnormal phenomena. The first is that one political Party, which calls itself as representing the Malays, namely, U.M.N.O., has never taken part in the Government's campaign to promote the national language. This causes people to doubt what they say they represent. In actual fact, Malay is their mother tongue. And now the P.A.P. Government has made Malay the national language and has encouraged all people, including non-Malays, to learn Malay. Yet U.M.N.O. has not responded to our appeal, They have totally disregarded and ignored our National Language Month and the promotion of the national language. This is regrettable.

    Another political Party is the Barisan Sosialis. They have always been indifferent to the promotion of the national

Column: 697

language as though it has nothing to do with them. Yet they claim themselves to be a political Party that supports Malay as the national language. Their claim judged from their action is very doubtful.

    In addition to sponsoring and conducting the National Language Month or National Language Week, the Dewan also produces literature in the national language. But I feel that there are other fields of work which the Dewan has not been able to undertake.

3.15 p.m.

    I do not know whether it will be able to do work in other fields, such as the compilation of a new Malay dictionary, because when we learn the Malay language, we need more reference books of this nature. Although there are Malay dictionaries available in the bookshops, they were compiled several years ago, and the new words are not found in them.

    I also suggest that the Dewan should pay more attention to the promotion of the national language. I feel that the holding of National Language Month once a year is not enough. In addition, it should also hold forums and discussion groups on the national language to encourage and promote its use. For instance, it can encourage students from the primary or secondary schools to learn the national language so that the study of the national language can be undertaken jointly by all people concerned. This will be a great help in the promotion of the national language.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, as we know, the national language is accepted by all, as it concerns us and transcends political consideration. The Government is conscious of the need to promote and propagate the study of the national language and also to provide all possible facilities and encouragement to the people to acquire proficiency in it.

    In 1965, two National Language Months have been held, and as in previous national language campaigns, a

Column: 698

representative committee with members from the public and private sectors, including employers from the Chamber of Commerce and the Manufacturers' Association, and cultural organisations have considered the overall programme of activities.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Sembawang has suggested that U.M.N.O. and other political Parties did not participate fully in past campaigns and that they should do so in the future. With regard to the absence of participation by U.M.N.O., I feel that this question can best be answered by U.M.N.O. themselves. Very unfortunately, they have been rejected by the people to hold seats in this House. However, I shall take advantage of this opportunity to enlighten the House later on our language policy.

    I am sure that the Member for Sembawang will agree that the national language is common to and concerns all our people, and efforts to popularise and propagate the study of it should also be a national issue transcending barriers of political ideology, since it has been accepted by all. We therefore hope that in this pragmatic approach of persuading - I said persuading, not forcing - the people to study the national language, members of other political Parties will also fully and actively play their part, since this is in the best interest of the nation.

    For the information of the Member for Sembawang, I should like to state that the Government has spent no less than $26,000 on the two national language campaigns carried out this year. And the activities included debates, essay competitions, forums, cultural activities, book exhibitions and, above all, the publication by the Ministry of Culture of a book known as the Istilah, a book on Malay terms and designations of the Government.

    With regard to the suggestion by the Member for Sembawang on the necessity to publish a dictionary comprising new words and new terms in the national language, this is indeed a very good suggestion which is worthy of consideration. The Ministry is, in fact,

Column: 699

now in the process of making such a compilation. The House will agree with me that it will be highly uneconomical for us to publish a small dictionary comprising perhaps 20 to 30 words. So until such time as the new terms and new words have been collected and put into a sort of dictionary, this book will be circulated first to Members of Parliament and the various Government departments and then to members of the public.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am also grateful to the Member for Sembawang for allowing me this opportunity to explain to the House the general attitude of the Government of Singapore to the national language issue. In a multi-racial, multi-lingual and multi-cultural society like Singapore, we believe that the only way to achieve results is by means of persuasion, that the people should take up the national language as a matter of pride as citizens of Singapore, and not by force, threats and intimidation. As we see, these are very commonly the tactics employed by the language extremists in Malaysia.

    Sir, we cannot run away from the reality that whatever statements and opinions are uttered across the Causeway do affect Singapore, and during the short two years that we were in Malaysia, the amount of intimidation and threats by the language extremists did to some extent influence the thinking of the people on the national language issue. We believe that by friendly persuasion and conviction people will take pride, and not fear, in the national language. However, this is the situation and the Singapore Government is now left with the job of clearing the minds of dissatisfied people in this matter.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am very grateful for the explanation given by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture. I withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Inche Mahmud Awang (Kampong Kapor)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1002 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1331.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, is this Ministry aware that the News Section (TV and Radio) has issued news emanating from our neighbouring countries whose attitude is one of animosity towards us? Sometimes the news is given wide publicity. Is this News Section still under the control of the Ministry in Malaysia, or are the officers in this News Section run by officers seconded from the Malaysian News Section? What is the attitude or policy of the Ministry on the News Section which issues news emanating from our neighbouring countries whose attitude is one of enmity towards us? What are the changes whereby the news items of our country can be given more prominence than the news from our neighbouring countries? Is it possible that news regarding our country can be given wider publicity?

    Mr S. Rajoo (Farrer Park)(In Tamil): Mr Speaker, Sir, the radio and television together provide entertainment and scope for the acquisition of knowledge. Radio programmes cannot be of much use to the people unless they are set out properly. The Tamil programmes over the radio and on T.V. have not improved very much. The Government has allocated 15 hours a day for its Tamil programme over the radio. The attitude seems to be one of trying to while away the 15 hours by ---

    The Chairman: The item relates itself to the News Section. If the Member is embarking on the whole policy relating to the time allocation of the language programmes, he is out of order.

    Mr Rajoo(In Tamil): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am just speaking in general. I am only quoting this as an example. Old tapes are used and old programmes are broadcast on holidays and special occasions, and the officers thus feel that

Column: 701

they have discharged their duties. Perhaps some of them think that the Minister of State for Culture does not understand Tamil. But they must not forget that thousands of people listen to the news and view television.

    T.V. has been functioning for the last three years and yet there have been no improvements. Outside artistes are not given an opportunity to take part. In general, local radio artistes take part in more programmes. I think that three years is a long period to effect some improvements.

3.30 p.m.

    In every nook and corner of Singapore, radios are turned on. But they broadcast mostly Kuala Lumpur programmes. The reason for this is that the programmes here are not up to standard. The Singapore Government gets $12 annually as a radio licence fee from each subscriber. And he has to be satisfied with just listening to the Kuala Lumpur programmes. About seven or eight years ago, a Commission of Inquiry was set up to investigate into the Tamil Section of Radio Singapore. After two or three years of that, I was told that the programmes were good. The Ministry should try to do something to bring up the standard of the programmes.

    The highly paid officials of the Radio and T.V. section are not doing their duties properly. They have given most of their jobs to the lower paid staff. I think this is one of the reasons for the lower standard in the programmes. In some cases, applications for broadcasters in the Radio and T.V. sections are invited. Both men and women are asked to apply. A voice test is given to the applicants. When these tests are given to women especially, they are given dialogues of love scenes to read instead, and the men, in reply, give their opinions. In fact, people who are really interested in such talents are shocked by tests of this nature. I hope the Ministry of Culture will be able to remedy this state of affairs so that better programmes can be provided for the people.

Column: 702



    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, I have a little complaint against T.V. and Radio.

    The Chairman: The News Section, I hope!

    Mr Ho See Beng: Yes, the News Section. It seems to me that the T.V. and Radio News Section have given more coverage to the Barisan Sosialis than to the Back-benchers of our Government. Some time last week, when Dr Lee Siew Choh was giving a Press conference, a very good report was broadcast over the radio and T.V. I remember the radio and T.V. did not report even one line of my Budget speech, which contained about eight and a half pages. This is my complaint, Sir.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will start off with the complaint about the news. There are several daily news casts over the radio and television in the four language streams in Singapore. The radio news is from both the medium and shortwave network. This means that it is heard not only in our neighbouring countries but also in those countries that are much further. As has already been pointed out in the Address by the President, every effort will be made by the Government to publicise fully its policies and activities, especially its reaction to political situations in other countries, particularly in the neighbouring territories. This is essential to Singapore's position as an independent country whose future depends on worldwide orientation and effort. It is equally important to provide an international content in our daily news bulletins for our people and, especially, cover politics and happenings in our neighbouring countries, particularly Malaysia with whom our connections and interest are basic.

    With regard to the comment by the Member for Kampong Kapor, namely, that the radio and T.V. have given an undue over-coverage of countries outside Singapore, particularly in Malaysia, I should like to state that we are a democratic country and we are not afraid of any adverse opinions or comments on us. We also feel that the radio and T.V. are a public media which can

Column: 703

provide a channel of knowledge to the people, and we are not afraid of letting the people know the truth although it is painful at times!

    Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the complaint by the Member for Farrer Park on programme planning, I wish to assure the House that every programme on T.V. and radio is carefully planned and timed, particularly according to the festive seasons of the various communities. However, there are ---

    Mr S. V. Lingam (Aljunied): Shortcomings!

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Shortcomings. I thank the Member for Aljunied for that word. There are shortcomings and difficulties that confront us from time to time, difficulties relating to obtaining good artistes - for we wish to maintain a fairly high if not decent standard - and also the technical difficulties. Over the last few years, Radio Singapore and Television have grown considerably. But the studio has not grown. We hope that when the new studio is completed, there will be an overall improvement, to the satisfaction of those Members who have complained about the standard or quality of the programmes.

    The statement by the Member for Bras Basah goes to show that we are more than fair to the Barisan Sosialis, notwithstanding the fact that they have decided to boycott the sittings of this House.
